incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On August 29, 2019, at approximately 1350 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location and met with Mr. Jeremy Webb, Store Manager, ABC Auto Parts. Mr. Webb explained to the Investigator that the spill was discovered when employees arrived to open the store.  The tote was cracked, and cause of the crack was unknown.   The spill had flowed from the tote to the concrete in the loading area and had flowed south on Mill Street for two blocks to Cedar Street.   The spill was be only to concrete and did not appear to impact waters of the State.  Lone Star Hazmat crews had power washed the oil on Mill Street and had placed absorbent around the leaking tote.       

On August 29, 2019, the investigator, issued verbal directives to Mr. Richard Lenius and Mr. Jeremy Webb, to submit a written report to the TCEQ Tyler Regional Office for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On February 11, 2022, at approximately 1445 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries; Ms. Christina Crockett, Emergency Management Coordinator, Anderson County; and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The truck involved in the accident was still at the location and was leaking pelletized ammonium nitrate and the tractor was leaking diesel fuel from the saddle tanks.  LSB Industries and Lone Star Hazmat crews were removing the ammonium nitrite from the roadway and placing it into another trailer for reuse.  Lone Star Hazmat crews had placed absorbent on the leaking diesel fuel and were taking precautions that the diesel fuel did not mix with the ammonium nitrite.  The spill appeared to be contained and was only on the paved portion of Highway 287.  There did not appear to be an impact waters of the State from the spill.  Mr. Larue indicated that he planned on reusing the recovered ammonium nitrate. 

On February 11, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

Ms. Aguirre contacted the RRC Oil and Gas Division Districts 1 & 2 to notify of the ER incident. Mr. Orlando Caridad, Engineering Specialist with the RRC District 1, received the notification and ensured the incident was addressed by the RRC personnel. The incident is under the RRC jurisdiction. No further actions are required.
description: On October 25, 2021, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Laredo Region Office (LRO) received an Emergency Response (ER) notification of a crude oil release at the Plains Pipeline LP (GPS:28.365556, -99.64750), near Catarina, Dimmit County, Texas.

comments: On October 15, 2021, Mr. Bill Ross Emergency Response Coordinator (ERC) with TCEQ R14, contacted Ms. Azia Benavides, with BDEC, to gather additional information. Ms. Benavides estimated 1200 pounds (140 gallons) of polypropylene glycol entered a 1000-acre cooling pond due to a leak in a heat exchanger tube. The leak was stopped, and the heat exchanger tube was repaired. The point of discharge into the cooling pond was approximately 1-mile away from an outfall into Oso Bay. Propylene glycol is readily biodegradable under aerobic conditions in freshwater, in seawater and in soil. Therefore, propylene glycol is considered as not persistent in the environment.

description:
On September 28, 2021, at approximately 21:00 hours, Mr. Blas Guadiana, Environmental Investigator with the TCEQ Laredo Region Office (LRO), received an emergency response email regarding a tank battery fire ensuing after a lightning strike at the Dimmit County Saltwater Disposal (SWD) facility causing a release of oil, saltwater condensate and H2S gas. The initial report was submitted by Mr. Fernando Perez, District Coordinator with the Texas Division of Emergency Management. On September 29, 2021, Mr. Guadiana contacted Ms. Christine Cardona, Dimmit County Emergency Management Coordinator, to inquire on the specifics regarding this incident. Ms. Cardona confirmed the incident occurred due to lightning impacting a tank battery causing a fire to ensue. 

Additionally, there was a release of oil, saltwater condensate and H2S gas. The oil and saltwater condensate were contained in the facility containment zone. Ms. Cardona stated Dimmit County Fire Department, City of Asherton Volunteer Fire Department, Dimmit County Sheriff's Office and Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) Troopers responded to the incident. At the time of the incident winds were from the south-southwest. DPS and Sheriff's department identified the nearest property to be located approximately 10 miles southwest of the location of the incident. However, no residents were present at the time of the incident. A shelter in place order was issued in the nearest township of Asherton (Dimmit County), Tx.

The same day, Mr. Guadiana contacted Fire Chief Alonso Carmona with the Dimmit County Fire Department, for an update on the fire incident. Chief Carmona stated that the fire was controlled at approximately 03:00 hours and over 100 gallons of fire suppressant foam was used. Chief Carmona stated no run-off of the fire suppressant foam had occurred.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On March 15, 2022, at approximately 0830 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Manager, Crow Towing.  The truck involved in the spill had been removed.  Crow towing crews were hand excavating the impacted soils due to the underground utilities at the location.  The spill did not appear to have impacted waters of the State.  

On March 18, 2022, at approximately 1400 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Manager, Crow Towing.   Crews had excavated the area, but overnight rains had filled the excavation with water.  Mr. McHam requested the investigator look at the site and determine if it need more excavation.  The investigator observed impacted soils and a sheen on the water in the excavation.  The investigator requested that additional impacted soils be excavated at the site.  Mr. McHam agreed and indicated that crews would remove the water from the excavation and continue to hand dig to remove the impacted soils.      

On March 15, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Ron McHam, Project Manager, Crow Towing to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

description: On November 30, 2018, at 1709 hours, Entergy Texas Inc. reported a spill 3 gallons of hydraulic fluid near 29.990632, -94.397377, Nome (Jefferson County), Texas.  The reported cause of spill was equipment failure.  The spill occurred on November 30, 2018, at 1605 hours and impacted water.

comments: On February 17, 2022, at approximately 1230 hours, the investigator contacted, Mr. Josh Gibbons, Company Contact with CSI Compressco. The investigator informed Mr. Gibbons that he was on his way to inspect the spill site and requested for Mr. Gibbons to meet him. Mr. Gibbons agreed to meet the investigator at the location. At approximately 1515 hours the investigator arrived at the location of the spill. The tractor trailer involved in the accident had been removed and there were no response personnel at the location. The investigator walked the spill site and trace amounts of sheen could be seen on the road and ditch. At approximately 1530 hours Mr. Chris Ellis and Mr. Josh Gibbons met with the investigator at the spill site. The investigator questioned the group how much diesel was spilled, and it was estimated that less than 25 gallons of diesel was spilled in the area. Mr. Ellis explained to the group the remediation actions that were going to take place to contain the spill. Mr. Ellis informed the group that a combination of absorbents and booms would be used to contain the diesel and the impacted soils would be removed in the following days. Mr. Gibbons gave his approval and Lone Star personnel commence to stabilize the area. The investigator monitored the progress and the area appeared to be stabilize. The investigator gave verbal directives to Mr. Ellis to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

description: A call was received at the TCEQ Region 2 Lubbock Office at approximately 1100 hours on February 28, 2022. Per the Texas Oil or Hazardous Substances Discharge or Spill Report, road debris punctured a side saddle tank of a tractor trailer and approximately 10 gallons of diesel fuel was released onto the ground at 1001 East 74th Street Lubbock, Texas 79404. The reportable quantity for diesel fuel is 25 gallons. Per the report, the Responsible Party is Frito Lay, located at 7701 Legacy Drive Plano, Texas 75024.  Ms. Crystal Hunt, TCEQ investigator, contacted Mr. Matt Testa, Spill Center, whom reported the spill to VelocityEHS, to confirm the incident. Mr. Testa stated it was company policy to report any amount spilled, even if it was not a reportable quantity.

action: On October 20 and 22, 2021, a response action report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office.  The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, and disposal documentation.  Absorbent booms and pads were used to contain the spill.  Coco absorbent and power brooms were used to clean the impacted concrete.  A section of soil over concrete was removed.  The waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417C) in Alvarado (Johnson County), Texas.  Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On March 16, 2022, at approximately 1100 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill.  The investigator met with Ms. Lori Brown, Project Manager, Fuller Environmental.  Fuller personnel were removing the diesel fuel from the storm drains and parking lot of the neighboring Dairy Queen Restaurant.  The investigator went to Nat 4 and met with Mr. Gary Sing, Clerk, Nat 4.  Mr. Sing explained that sometime the morning of March 15, 2022, had truck overfilled the saddle tank.  This resulted in a spill of diesel fuel to the diesel truck fueling area.  The fuel flowed from the dispenser area to the west onto Dairy Queen property. A phone call was made to Mr. Jaspreet Nat, Owner, Nat 4.  Mr. Nat indicated that it was a small spill, and he was not going to clean the diesel up on the dairy queen property. The investigator explained that Nat 4 was responsible for cleanup of fuel spills at the gas station, including the spills that leave gas station property.


Prior to the investigator departing the location, Fuller Environmental crews finished cleaning the Dairy Queen parking lot and flushing the storm drains.  Ms. Fuller indicated that they were called by the Owner of the Dairy Queen at the request of Canton Fire Department.  Ms. Brown indicated that she would be attempting to bill Nat 4 for the for the cleanup of the spill.  


Verbal directives were issued, on March 16, 2022, Mr. Jaspreet Nat, Owner, Nat 4, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.
description: On March 15, 2022, at 1917 hours, Mr. Bryan Kelly, Owner, Dairy Queen and on March 16, 2022, at 1001 hours, Mr. Josh Milton, Officer, Canton Police, called with separate reports of a spill (Chemtel Nos. 20220813 and 20220818).  On March 15, 2022, at approximately 8:00 hours a truck overfilled the saddle tank.  This resulted in a release of an estimated 30 gallon of diesel fuel to the concrete of the truck fueling area.

action:
On December 15, 2021, a response action report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office.  The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, and disposal documentation.  On December 9, 2021, approximately 80 gallons of diesel fuel was spilled from the passenger side saddle tank of a tractor trailer. The cause of the spill was a motor vehicle accident involving a tractor trailer and a passenger truck. The spill impacted the roadway only. No waters of the state were impacted by this spill. The responsible party contracted CTR Environmental to remediate the spill.

CTR Environmental stopped the remaining diesel from escaping the damaged tank by filling it with absorbent. Absorbent material was then applied around the crash site and to areas of pooling fuel. Spill Tackle was used to cover the remaining spread. Impacted area was then scrubbed with Skid Steer and a pickup broom; spent absorbent was contained in a dump trailer. Area was then treated with ELMN8 and more Spill Tackle, scrubbed and evenly spread. The waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417C) located in Alvarado (Johnson County), Texas.

Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On March 11, 2022, at approximately 1115 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Ryan Holt, Owner, Holt Industries; Mr. Tim Matingly, Environmental, Tarrant Regional Water District and Mr. Shane Renberg, Fire Marshall, Henderson County.  Holt Industries personnel were actively containing the diesel in Cedar Creek Reservoir using booms.  A strong North wind was keeping the diesel fuel pushed against the bulkhead on the south shore of the lake and against the bulkhead where the spill occurred.  Booms had been placed in the lake to contain the spill.  Holt crews began vacuuming the diesel fuel from the lake.  In addition, the barges in the lake where the spill occurred were removed from the lake for decontamination.  

On March 12, 2022, at approximately 0850 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Ryan Holt, Owner, Holt Industries; Mr. Tim Matingly, Environmental, Tarrant Regional Water District and Mr. Shane Renberg, Fire Marshall, Henderson County.  Holt Industries personnel overnight had removed most of diesel fuel from the lake in the area where the spill occurred.  However, some of the diesel flowed into a small cove approximately 200 yards southeast of there the spill occurred.  Holt Industries personnel had contained the diesel in the cove with booms and absorbent.  The absorbent soaked with diesel was being removed from the lake and containerized.  

On March 14, 2022, at approximately 0900, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Ryan Holt, Owner, Holt Industries.  Holt crews were finishing lake cleanup activities.  Only minor sheens were observed along the bulkhead and in the small cove.  Mr. Holt indicated that they would be excavating the impacted soils in the next few days.

On March 11, 2022, the investigator, gave to directives to Mr. Kyle Mosely, Project Manager, Copasa, Inc. and Mr. Ryan Holt, Owner, Holt Industries, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On July 7, 2021, at approximately 1200 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. David Dipple, Environmental Project Manager, Pilot; Mr. James Jordan, Utilities Director, City of Sulphur Springs; Mr. Richard Lenius, President, Lone Star Hazmat.  Lone star crews were vacuuming the biodiesel from the roadside ditch and the pump vaults for the underground storage tanks.  Mr. Dippel indicated that the leak was from a pipe from the biodiesel tank to the mixing pumps.  The release was pure biodiesel and contained only plant oils.  An underflow dam had been constructed in the roadside ditch to contain the biodiesel in case of a rain.  Mr. Dipple explained that vacuuming operations will continue until there is no longer biodiesel fuel seeping from the soils and in the tank vaults.  

On November 1, 2021, at approximately 1200 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Tony Sebrew, Maintenance Manger, STEMCO.   The spilled Zinc Water entered the storm drain at the building and discharged into an unnamed tributary of Eastman Lake Creek.  Mr. Sebrew did not know the concentration of the Zinc solution that was spilled.  There were no dead fish or any other observable impact to the water in the unnamed creek.   Mr. Sebrew indicated that they would continue to monitor the creek to determine if there are any impacts.    

Verbal directives were issued, on October 29, 2021, to Ms. Stacy Cabrera, EHS Manager, STEMCO, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

action:
On December 15, 2021, the TCEQ DFW Regional Office received a response action report from Aramark Uniform & Career Apparel, Inc. (Aramark) for Incident Number (No.) 371355. The report included a description of the accidental discharge or spill and its cause; the identification of any potential danger to human health or safety, or the environment; the duration of the accidental discharge or spill, including exact dates and times; indication of whether or not the accidental discharge or spill had not been corrected; the time that the discharge or spill would be expected to continue if not already corrected; and any steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence, and to mitigate any adverse effects. 

On December 10, 2021, approximately 1,000 - 2,000 gallons of partially treated wastewater was spilled from the Aramark facility located at 1900 Empire Central, Dallas, TX 75235.  The spill impacted land only.  The cause of the spill was a mechanical issue within a wastewater transfer pump that resulted in an overflow event.  The responsible party contracted CG Environmental to remediate the spill.  

Based on the review of the submitted documentation, Aramark has completed reporting requirements in accordance with the Title 30 Texas Administrative Code 327 Spill Prevention and Control rules. No further action is warranted from Aramark at this time.

comments: The reportable quantity (RQ) for motor oil is 25 gallons. After reviewing the details of the incident, it was determined that appropriate actions had been taken by the responsible party to address the aforementioned release. Since the release was below the reportable quantity, a final clean-up report is not required to be submitted to TCEQ LRO. At this time no further action is required.
action:
CRST retained Cura Emergency Services to manage the environmental remediation on their behalf. The same day, a crew from Enhanced Environmental Emergency (E3) was deployed to assess and remediate the impacted site.  E3 personnel placed granular absorbents on the soil and a degreasing agent on the concrete to remove staining. E3 then utilized excavation tools to perform an excavation of the impacted soil. All motor oil impacted material was collected and contained in three 55-gallon drums for transport and disposal. This incident did not meet the criteria for Homeland Security notification.

On February 7, 2022, the final Hazardous Material Incident report was delivered to the TCEQ LRO. According to the report, a total of 10-gallons of motor oil were collected by utilizing a drum vacuum and granular absorbents. All impacted material was collected in three 55-gallon drums for transport and disposed at Terrabella Environmental.

reg_ent_name: DELTA PROCESS MANAGEMENT ENVIROTECH CHEMICAL SERVICES
comments: The RE tested the pH of the water and the porous materials from the building. The water was at an acceptable pH for disposal to the City of Levelland, Publicly Owned Treatment Works, and the porous materials were taken to the City of Levelland Landfill. The report stated the soil around the production unit was tested and the pH was neutral.
action: Mr. Good stated the deluge water from the fire suppression system remained mostly onsite/inside the building, but that there was some runoff that went under the rail spur. Mr. Good stated they would be pumping and storing the water from the building until proper disposal could be arranged and that they were in contact with the Lubbock and Western Railway regarding the material under the rails and the car. They decided to leave the cars in place at that time. At the time of the release, the FD had shutdown traffic on Highway 114 and air traffic over the facility. At the time TCEQ was notified of the release, both shutdowns had been lifted.
description: On September 20, 2021, Ms. Coley received notification from the Texas Railroad Commission (RRC) of a spill of acetic acid at Delta Process Management Envirotech Chemical Services, located at 2119 Progressive Place, Levelland, Hockley County, Texas. Mr. Scott Good, Plant Manager, stated at 0330 hours he received a call from the fire monitoring service stating water flow had been detected and that the Levelland Fire Department (FD) had been dispatched. Mr. Good stated he met the FD at the plant gate where he could see broken piping at the tops of the processing area. Mr. Good stated a 6,000-gallon reactor tank had been knocked of its footings and was resting on the ground. Mr. Good stated at the time there was a batch of 15% peracetic acid being mixed and approximately 3,000 gallons was released.

action:
On October 11, 2021, a final cleanup spill report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office. The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, sample results and disposal documentation. On September 02, 2021, several tractor trailers caught fire in a parking lot located at 2000 West Marshall Drive, Grand Prairie (Dallas County), Texas 75051. As a result of the firefighting activities, water and diesel flowed towards three stormwater inlets, which connects with the Cottonwood Creek. Poly-Trucking contracted Sunbelt and Apex to perform response actions. When Sunbelt arrived at the area, the crew assessed the impact to the creek and placed a floating boom downstream of the impacted area; a second boom was placed 900 feet downstream of the first boom. Additional absorbent booms were placed at the stormwater outfall. Sunbelt crew captured the floating material using a pump and a floating skimmer, and the crew later washed the stormwater outfall and collected the water in a vacuum truck. Sunbelt also decontaminated the impacted parking lot area and excavated the contaminated soil adjacent to the creek and stormwater outlet. 

Apex collected several soil and water samples from different sections of the impacted area to determine the contamination levels in the creek and adjacent banks. The samples were sent to Eurofins Xenco lab (National Environmental Laboratory Accreditation Program Certification No. T104704295-21-28) in Dallas, Texas to be tested for benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, xylene, and total petroleum hydrocarbons.  Additional water quality data (temperature, conductivity, dissolved oxygen, pH, and oxidation reduction potential) were collected with handheld monitors. The confirmation samples were consistent with background conditions. 

The wastewater collected during the cleanup activities was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417C) in Alvarado, Texas, and Valicor Environmental Services Hutchins (Solid Waste Registration No. 95791) in Hutchins, Texas. The impacted soil, booms, and pads waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill in Alvarado, Texas. Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

action: Performance Chemical and Union Pacific contracted US Ecology to perform the remediation. Union Pacific also contracted GHD to conduct air monitoring. US Ecology contracted Lone Star Hazmat, who initially responded to the spill. Initial remediation actions consisted of off-loading product from the damage totes to prevent further leakage. The Barstow volunteer fire department used firefighting foam for vapor suppression. Lone Star Hazmat and US Ecology used absorbent booms and soil berms to prevent the chemical from moving upstream and downstream. A vac truck will be used to remove the free-standing liquid and contaminated soil will be excavated by a specially trained team from US Ecology due to the proximity of the spill to a railroad track bridge.

action:
On September 1, 2021, at 0824, Mr. Louder was contacted by Mr. Patrick Warnick, Targa Resources. Mr. Warnick provided initial notification regarding the release of approximately 40-gallons of CHEMTHERM. The release occurred from a temporarily placed chemical tote that developed a crack after being set near a heater that was to be filled with CHEMTHERM.

On September 3, 2021, Mr. Louder contacted Ms. Crystal Denson, Assistant Director, District 7C, Railroad Commission of Texas, in San Angelo, Texas. It was determined that as the spill occurred during production, it fell under the jurisdiction of the RRC. Mr. Louder provided notification to Mr. Warnick that day that the incident would fall under the jurisdiction of the RRC, and information regarding the spill had been provided via email to the RRC District 7C office. 

All of the aforementioned email correspondence is attached to the incident report (Attachment 1).

action:
On January 3, 2022, a response action report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office.  The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, and disposal documentation.  On November 19, 2021, approximately 50 gallons of diesel fuel was spilled from a damaged saddle tank.  The spill impacted land only.  The cause of the spill was a motor vehicle accident.  The responsible party contracted Cura Environmental Services, L.C. (CES) to remediate the spill.

CES dispatched a crew from TAS Environmental (TAS) to assess and remediate the spill as necessary. Prior to TAS arrival on-site, the local Hutchins Fire Department had deployed granular absorbents to the release. Upon their arrival, TAS crews deployed additional granular absorbents to the area and worked them in with hand tools. All impacted material was collected, stored in two 55-gallon drums, and prepared for transport. The waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Valicor Environmental Services (Solid Waste Registration (SWR) Number (No.) 95791), located in Hutchins (Dallas County), Texas.

Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

description:
On January 20, 2022, at 1051 hours, the TCEQ Harlingen Region Office received a call from the City of Roma Water Department Supervisor Jose Vela who provided initial notification prior to contacting the National Response Center (NRC) about approximately 600 - 800 gallons of 10% sodium hypochlorite (liquid bleach) spill that impacted water and soil. The incident was discovered on January 19, 2022, around 1930 hours local time. The cause is a tractor trailer tanker (transporter) erroneously unloading into the wrong storage tank. The transporter was delivering approximately 4,500 gallons of Aquamineยฎ (liquid ammonium sulfate) to an empty labeled storage tank. After being instructed by the Plant Operator on duty to what port to hookup, the transporter misunderstood the instructions. While the operator went to open the fill valve and notify the transporter that the valve had been opened, the transporter opened the tanker pressurized valve and started to unload chemical into the wrong storage tank. Immediately, the liquid ammonium sulfate in the tank and the sodium hypochlorite solution reacted, causing the storage tank to burst and chemical to be spilled into the containment. The containment was compromised causing sodium hypochlorite to spill into a stormwater drain that led to a ravine and into the Rio Grande River. The water plant was not disrupted and was able to continue production. No human and non-human injuries were reported.

Emergency hazmat companies Clean Harbors from San Antonio, Chemical Response Remediation Contractors (CRRC) from Harlingen (subcontracted by Clean Harbors), and Broadbent from San Antonio (subcontracted by CRRC) were obtained for remediation and cleanup. Clean Harbors and CRRC responded around 0800 hours in the morning securing the spilled material and awaiting an NRC incident number to continue remediation. Broadbent's estimated time of arrival to collect samples at the ravine is the morning of January 21, 2022.

The responsible parties (RP) are the City of Roma and Linden Bulk Transportation, LLC. The RP has contained the released material and is awaiting the hazmat companies to complete remediation and soil analysis. The RP has been advised to remove, properly dispose of the generated waste, and remediate the soil to background conditions. The RP has been advised to submit a response action plan within 30 days of the discovery of the release. Also, to submit cleanup photos, disposal documents, and soil analysis results once the cleanup response has been completed to demonstrate compliance with Title 30 Texas Administrative Code (TAC) ยง327.5 - Spill Prevention and Control requirements.

comments:
On September 16, 2021, at approximately 1600 hours, the investigator arrived at the location of the spill.  The investigator met with Ms. Leona Colquitt, Property Owner and Mr. Dale McAlonan, Property Owner.  A large amount of what appeared to be used motor oil and diesel fuel was observed on the pond and creek on the property. The Creek was an unnamed Tributary of Prairie Creek in Sabine River Basin (Segment 0505).   Mr. McAlonan explained that a few weeks prior he had contacted TXDOT about the oil in the creek.  The oil appeared to have been dumped on the TXDOT right of way from an unknown entity.   The investigator walked the unnamed tributary up stream to the TXDOT Right of Way.  The amount of oil in the creek was estimated to be 200 gallons.

The Investigator contacted Mr. Chris Wiatrek, Emergency Management Liaison, TCEQ and mobilized Allied International Emergency as a state lead contractor to the location.  The State lead contractor was mobilized since the responsible party for the spill was unknown and the oil was in a creek.  This state funded cleanup was assigned TCEQ Project Number 2022-03.
action: The TCEQ will continue to oversee the state funded cleanup of the spill (TCEQ Project Number 2022-03).

comments:
On November 16, 2021, at approximately 1600 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Ms. Maria Bedarte, Environmental Specialist, TIC Industrial Company.  The spilled mineral oil flowed onto the ground to the West of the transformer.  Some of the soils where the spill had occurred was excavated and there were absorbent booms surrounding the spill.  The spill was contained and did not appear to be impacting waters of the State.  Ms. Bedarte indicated that contractors would be excavating the impacted soils in the next few days.  

On November 16, 2021, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Ms. Maria Bedarte, Environmental Specialist, TIC Industrial Company, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On September 21, 2021, at approximately 2030 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill.  The investigator met with Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, Crow Towing and Mr. Tony, McGovern, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The trucks involved in the accident were onsite.  Crow Towing and Lone Star Hazmat crews were spreading sand on the roadway.  The epoxy wood glue had flowed over the roadway and in both the center median and the west bound shoulder of the interstate.  There did not appear to be an impact to waters of the State from the spill.  

On September 22, 2021, at approximately 1000 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill.  The trucks involved in the accident had been removed and there were no response personnel at the location.  The epoxy glue had been removed from the roadway, but there was liquid epoxy glue on the shoulder of the road.  There did not appear to be any impact from the spill to waters of the State.  The investigator contacted Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, Crow Towing.  Mr. McHam indicated that they will be excavating the impacted soils in the next few days. 

On September 21, 2021, the investigator, gave to directives to, Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

action: On January 09, 2022, a response action report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office. The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, sample results, and disposal documentation. It was determined that only the roadway was impacted. Absorbents were used to contain the spill and Microblaze was used to degrade the spilled diesel. The roadway was cleaned with a walk-behind recovery machine unit. The samples were analyzed by Eurofins Xenco, Dallas (National Environmental Laboratory Accreditation Program Certification No. T104704295-21-28) in Dallas, Texas for total petroleum hydrocarbons. The sample results were non-detect. The waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Valicor Environmental Services Hutchins (Solid Waste Registration No. 95791) in Hutchins (Dallas County), Texas. Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

description: On October 14, 2021 at 1030 hours, Mr. James Simon with Mid-County Express Gas Station (MC Express) reported a spill of an unknown quantity of gasoline from underground storage tank piping at their facility, located at 104 South Twin City Highway in Nederland (Jefferson County), Texas. During an onsite investigation conducted the same day by Texas Commission on Environmental Quality Region 10 (TCEQ R10) investigators, City of Nederland Fire Department (NFD) personnel estimated the volume of spilled material to be 150 gallons. The reported cause of the spill was equipment failure during pressure testing. The release occurred on October 14, 2021 at 1030 hours and impacted land.

comments:
On November 30, 2021, at approximately 0900 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. J. R. Tarpley, Manager, Atlas Oil Company and Mr. Tony McGovern, Project Manager Lone Star Hazmat.  Lone Star Hazmat crews were excavating the impacted soils from the spill.  The spill appeared to be contained and there did not appear to be an impact to waters of the State.

On November 21, 2021, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Ms. Megan Zettlemoyer, Environmental Manager, Atlas Oil Company, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On September 1, 2021, at 1448 hours, Mr. Tim Haven, XTO Energy, called with a report of a discharge of an estimated 4 barrels of crude oil onto the ground and an unnamed creek from a gathering pipeline. The GPS coordinates of the leak location are N 32.5937737 and W -095.20072168.  This became incident number 367595.

On September 1, 2021, at approximately 1600 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met Mr. Mark Foreman, XTO's EHS Field Representative. Mr. Foreman explained that the incident occurred due to a field crew accidentally puncturing the pipe with a T post.  Mr. Foreman explained that the pipeline had been isolated and work crews had applied booms, absorbents, and were currently using a vac truck to remove the oil. The oil appeared to be contained in what appeared to be a rudimentary dirt berm. The RRC will be monitoring the cleanup of this spill.
action: This incident was not classified as a Significant Incident.  Based on information obtained during the investigation, this spill was a RRC regulated release and did not involve a TCEQ Chapter 327 regulated spill.  The RRC will be monitoring the cleanup of the spill.

comments:
On October 28, 2021, at approximately 1600 hours, investigator Tom, Erny arrived at the location.  The investigator met with Mr. Jason Chamblee, Fire Chief, City of Kilgore.    The fire was emitting large quantities of black smoke.  High winds from the Northwest were blowing the smoke over southern Kilgore.  Highway 135 had been closed and the City of Kilgore was evacuating the nearby business in the industrial park.  Chief Chamblee decided to contain the fire at the facility and was spraying water on the fire from Highway 135. Fire personnel were not entering the facility.  Texas Forest Service personnel arrive at the incident at 1730 hours and installed a fire break around the facility to help contain the fire.    

On October 29, 2021, at approximately, 0930 hours, investigator Tom, Erny arrived at the location.  The investigator met with Mr. Robert King, Fire Captain, Kilgore Fire Department. Kilgore fire personnel were putting water on small visible fire on the various piles at the facility.  There were multiple smoldering piles of materials emitting significant smoke.  The investigator accompanied by Kilgore Fire Department entered the facility.  The site was large plies of metal recyclables that had become overgrown with vegetation. Most of the materials that burning in the fire were incidental to the metal recycling such as wire insulation, tires and miscellaneous plastics associated with with the metal recyclables.  There was no runoff was observed from the site and there did not appear to be an impact to waters of the state from firefighting operations.    

On October 30, 31 and November 1, 2021 the investigator drove by the site.  On all days there were multi piles of materials still smoldering emitting smoke.

On November 5, 2021, the investigator drove by the site.  There was no smoke observed emanating from the piles of material.
action: The incident is being referred to the TCEQ Tyler Waste Program for follow up and potential remediation.

The fire is generating large quantities of black smoke and the nearby businesses are being evacuated.

comments:
On December 14, 2021, at approximately 0930 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with, Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The truck involved in the accident was still present at the location and wreaker crews were attempting to upright the semi-truck. Lone Star hazmat crews had placed absorbent around the spilled diesel in the center median.  Mr. Gilbreath indicated that Lone Star crews would excavate the impacted soils after the truck is removed.  The spilled diesel fuel did not appear to be impacting waters of the State.   

On December 15, 2021, at approximately 1600 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill.  The semi-truck involved in the accident had been removed and there were no response personnel present at the location.  The area of impacted soils had been excavated and backfilled.    

On December 14, 2021, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

comments:
On February 11, 2022, at approximately 1445 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries; Ms. Christina Crockett, Emergency Management Coordinator, Anderson County; and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The truck involved in the accident was still at the location and was leaking pelletized ammonium nitrate and the tractor was leaking diesel fuel from the saddle tanks.  LSB Industries and Lone Star Hazmat crews were removing the ammonium nitrite from the roadway and placing it into another trailer for reuse.  Lone Star Hazmat crews had placed absorbent on the leaking diesel fuel and were taking precautions that the diesel fuel did not mix with the ammonium nitrite.  The spill appeared to be contained and was only on the paved portion of Highway 287.  There did not appear to be an impact waters of the State from the spill.  Mr. Larue indicated that he planned on reusing the recovered ammonium nitrate. 

On February 11, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

description:
On September 28, 2021, at approximately 21:00 hours, Mr. Blas Guadiana, Environmental Investigator with the TCEQ Laredo Region Office (LRO), received an emergency response email regarding a tank battery fire ensuing after a lightning strike at the Dimmit County Saltwater Disposal (SWD) facility causing a release of oil, saltwater condensate and H2S gas. The initial report was submitted by Mr. Fernando Perez, District Coordinator with the Texas Division of Emergency Management. On September 29, 2021, Mr. Guadiana contacted Ms. Christine Cardona, Dimmit County Emergency Management Coordinator, to inquire on the specifics regarding this incident. Ms. Cardona confirmed the incident occurred due to lightning impacting a tank battery causing a fire to ensue. 

Additionally, there was a release of oil, saltwater condensate and H2S gas. The oil and saltwater condensate were contained in the facility containment zone. Ms. Cardona stated Dimmit County Fire Department, City of Asherton Volunteer Fire Department, Dimmit County Sheriff's Office and Texas Department of Public Safety (DPS) Troopers responded to the incident. At the time of the incident winds were from the south-southwest. DPS and Sheriff's department identified the nearest property to be located approximately 10 miles southwest of the location of the incident. However, no residents were present at the time of the incident. A shelter in place order was issued in the nearest township of Asherton (Dimmit County), Tx.

The same day, Mr. Guadiana contacted Fire Chief Alonso Carmona with the Dimmit County Fire Department, for an update on the fire incident. Chief Carmona stated that the fire was controlled at approximately 03:00 hours and over 100 gallons of fire suppressant foam was used. Chief Carmona stated no run-off of the fire suppressant foam had occurred.

comments:
On January 14, 2022, at approximately 0900 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill.  The were no response personnel at the location and the truck involved in the spill had been removed.  There were absorbents placed onto the roadway and the spill did not appear to be any impact to soils or waters of the State.  

On January 14, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Ron McHam, Project Manager, Crow Towing to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

description: Spill report at facility.

comments: On December 9, 2021 at 1615 hours TCEQ investigators arrived on-site.  The RP informed TCEQ that the Lubbock Fire Department cleaned up the mercury spill and the remaining amount of mercury was placed into a glass jar with a lid.  The jar was left with the RP for proper disposal.
action: The RP called the Lubbock Fire Department and was informed by Poison Control not to use a vacuum to address the spill, evacuate the immediate area, to use a squeegee to assit with the cleanup, and ventilate the area.  Their protocol is to report the incicdent to the state.  On December 9, 2021 at 1347 hours the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality was notified of the spill.
description: On December 9, 2021, at 1347 hours the responsible party (RP) called the Poison Control number to infrom them that the RP recieved a package with a thermometer that leaked mercury into the packaging and on to the ground.  The amount of release is stated to be more than 1-2 teaspoons.  The RP is needing assistance with the cleanup.

comments: On March 3, 2021, at approximately 1215 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Ms. Christina Crockett, Emergency Management Coordinator, Anderson County and Mr. Ronnie Barnes, EHS Coordinator, Eagle Railcar Services.   The fire was burning when the investigator arrived at the location. The fire occurred in a baghouse containing sand blast waste.  The waste burning the baghouse was Class 2 Non-Hazardous waste.  The cause of the fire was unknown at the time of the investigation.  Elkhart Fire Department personnel extinguished the fire while the investigator was onsite and the shelter in place order had been lifted. action: Based on information obtained during the investigation, the incident did not involve a 30 TAC 327 reportable quantity.  The Incident is being closed.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On February 11, 2022, at approximately 1445 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries; Ms. Christina Crockett, Emergency Management Coordinator, Anderson County; and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The truck involved in the accident was still at the location and was leaking pelletized ammonium nitrate and the tractor was leaking diesel fuel from the saddle tanks.  LSB Industries and Lone Star Hazmat crews were removing the ammonium nitrite from the roadway and placing it into another trailer for reuse.  Lone Star Hazmat crews had placed absorbent on the leaking diesel fuel and were taking precautions that the diesel fuel did not mix with the ammonium nitrite.  The spill appeared to be contained and was only on the paved portion of Highway 287.  There did not appear to be an impact waters of the State from the spill.  Mr. Larue indicated that he planned on reusing the recovered ammonium nitrate. 

On February 11, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Jason Larue, Manager, LSB Industries and Mr. Matt Gilbreath, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On April 14, 2022, at approximately 1100 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill. There were no emergency response personnel present.  The spilled mineral oil impacted soils had been covered with poly sheeting and booms had been placed in the bar ditch. There was no visual evidence of a sheen on the water in the bar ditch past the immediate area of where the mineral oil was contained with booms.       

On April 14, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Jim Kerlin to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

description: On April 6, 2022, Mr. Robert Lewis, TCEQ Environmental Investigator, received an Emergency Response (ER) notification regarding a crude oil spill at a Red Byrd Oil, LLC facility located at Texas Highway 85 near Big Wells (Dimmit County), Texas. Mr. Neil Rosales, Engineering Specialist III with the Railroad Commission of Texas (RRC) District 1&2 Office, was notified of the incident as well. The responsible party is identified as Red Byrd Oil, LLC. The affected media was land. No homeland security notification was required. No fish kill was reported.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On June 4, 2022, at approximately 1530 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Tony McGovern, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat.  The truck involved in the accident was still at the location.  The diesel fuel flowed across the parking lot and into a storm drain.  The fuel flowed down the storm drain and was pooled in the drainage ditch of Mall drive.  The spill was contained, and Lone Star hazmat crews were removing the diesel from the drainage ditch and storm drain. Absorbents had been placed on the diesel spill in the in the parking lot.  The spill did enter a storm drain, but there did not appear to be an impact to waters of the State from the spill.   

On June 4, 2022, the investigator, gave to directives to, Mr. Tony McGovern, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

comments:
On June 15, 2022, at approximately 1400 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill and met with Mr. Richard Lenius, President, Lone Star Hazmat and Mr. David James, Fire Chief, City of Sulphur Springs.  Lone Star Hazmat crews were washing the creek bank and vacuuming the animal fat out of the unnamed tributary.  The vacuumed animal fat was being placed into a frac tank stored onsite.  Lone Star Hazmat crews had dammed creek approximately 75 yards east of Jackson Street.  There was no animal fat observed below the dam.    

On June 15, 2022, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Richard Lenius, President, Lone Star Hazmat to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.
description:
On June 13, 2022, at 1612 hours, Mr Tony McGovern, Project Manager, Lone Star Hazmat; and at 1712 hours, Ms. Lorie Brown, Project Manager, Fuller Environmental called with a report of a spill (Chem-Tel No. 20221829 and 20221829, respectively).  On June 13, 2022, at approximately 1000 hours, a valve was left open in the Northeast Texas Farmers COOP.  This caused a release of an estimated 30,000 pounds of animal fat to the sanitary sewer in the plant.  The animal fat backed the sanitary sewer up causing it discharge from the sewer clean out in front of the Museum located at 4165 N. Jackson, Street, Sulphur Springs, Hopkins County, Texas.  The fat flowed south across the museum parking lot and into an unnamed tributary of Town Branch in the Sulphur River (Segment 0303).  The coordinates where the spill occurred are North 33.14165 degrees and West -95.59637 degrees.

The responsible party that spilled the animal fat is: 

Northeast Texas Farmers COOP
428 North Jackson Street
Sulphur Springs, Texas 75482
Phone 903-243-1994
POC: Mr. Gary Friddle, Manager

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
action:
INTRODUCTION

On August 1, 2016, Ms. Kara Allen, Environmental Investigator (EI) with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Region 13 โ San Antonio Office, conducted an Emergency Response Record Review (ER RR) to determine compliance with 30 Texas Administrative Code (TAC) 327 rules and requirements for an incident (Incident No. 234164) which occurred on May 30, 2016. The incident occurred on County Road (CR) 182 near Highway (Hwy) 72 in Kenedy, Karnes County, Texas. The incident, which involved an 18-wheeler rollover, resulted in the release of approximately 90 to 100 barrels of saltwater to the right-of-way and onto private property near the accident location.

BACKGROUND

On May 30, 2016, TCEQ San Antonio Office received notification of the spill at 12:16 p.m. The incident was reported as a salt water spill from an 18-wheeler rollover on CR 182. The incident was originally reported by Mr. Shelby Dupnik, Karnes County Emergency Management Coordinator. Ms. Allen, Primary Emergency Response Contact, called Mr. Dupnik to further discuss the incident. Mr. Dupnik stated that the tanker truck was half-full to full, and may have spilled more on private property than any other land. At that time, Mr. Dupnik had left a message with the Railroad  Commission of Texas (RRC) hotline and was awaiting a call back.

At approximately 12:45 p.m., Emergency Response Coordinator Ms. Joy Thurston-Cook contacted Mr. Chris Dzuik, TCEQ Region 13 EI, concerning the incident. Mr. Dzuik contacted Mr. Dupnik later that day regarding the specific location and details of the spill. Mr. Dupnik indicated that the accident resulted in the release of salt water to the right-of-way and onto private property near the accident location. Mr. Dzuik then contacted TCEQ San Antonio Office Waste Section Manager Mr. Cameron Lopez regarding the incident. It was determined at this time that Mr. Dzuik should depart to the location to assess any potential environmental concerns.

Mr. Dzuik arrived at the location at 1:30 p.m. and spoke with Mr. Dupnik who was still present at the scene. Mr. Dupnik informed Mr. Dzuik that there was a fatality associated to the accident and that Texas Department of Public Safety officers were evaluating the scene. Upon arrival at the scene, Mr. Dzuik was informed that the Responsible Party (RP) was Select Energy Services based in Kenedy, Texas. Representatives of the RP. Mr. Brandon Ziegel and Mr. Craig Fric, were at the scene to assess any environmental concerns. Mr. Fric indicated that CTI Environmental had been contracted to perform any necessary cleanup activities at the scene. Select Energy Services Representatives utilized another transport tanker, which had also arrived at the spill location, to transfer any remaining saltwater from the overturned tanker. Based on the information provided to Mr. Dzuik, approximately 90 to 100 barrels of saltwater were discharged. Mr. Dzuik provided contact information for the RRC to the RP so that the appropriate regulatory agencies were notified regarding the discharge. The RP contacted the RRC after hours contact line while Mr. Dzuik was present at the scene. RRC representatives indicated that a site visit would be performed the following day. Mr. Dzuik spoke with Mr. Alvin Theis, CTI Environmental representative, before departing the scene. Mr. Dzuik was informed that CTI Environmental would be handling the reporting requirements for the RP. Mr. Dzuik departed the scene shortly thereafter. Mr. Dzuik informed Mr. Theis that a representative from the TCEQ would be in contact regarding to whom any cleanup reports should be sent.
description: A 18 wheeler tanker truck rolled over and a large amount of saltwater leaked out.

action: This emergency response incident has been assigned and will be further investigated by an Environmental Investigator.
description: On February 19, 2020, at 10:18 PM, Mr. Eric Kuehn, Water Work Leader of the TCEQ San Angelo Region Office, received notification of diesel spill from a tractor trailer saddle tank during an accident. The spill was reported to have occurred 8 miles north of Eden on Highway 83. The amount of diesel spilled was reported to be 50 gallons to the land. The report indicated "VSC" was en route to complete the cleanup. Swift Transportation was reported to be the responsible party.

action: On April 15, 2020, a final cleanup spill report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office. The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, sample results, and disposal documentation. The diesel was contained with absorbent materials. The impacted soil was excavated. Crews used street brooms to scrub absorbent into the fuel on the asphalt surface. One confirmation soil sample was collected and sent to Technical Testing International (National Environmental Laboratory Accreditation Program Certification No. T104704325-20-21) in Arlington, Texas and analyzed for total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH). The confirmation sample was comparable to known backgrounds along highways. The waste generated during the response actions was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417C) at 9100 S I-35 W, Alvarado, Texas. Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On July 10, 2020, at approximately 1150 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill and met with, Mr. Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, Crow Towing.  The truck involved in the accident had been removed.  Crow Towing personnel were excavating the contaminated soils.  The spill was contained and in close proximity to Panther Creek.  However, the spill did not appear to be impacting waters of the State.      

On July 15, 2020, at approximately 1630 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill.  There was no response personnel present.  The impacted soils had been excavated and there did not appear to be any diesel fuel remaining at the location.  

On July 10, 2020, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, Crow Towing and Mr. Daryl Martin, Project Manager, Premium Environmental Services, to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.
description:
On July 8, 2020, at 1920 hours and on July 10, 2020 at 1632 hours Mr. Ron McHam, Environmental Program Manager, Crow Towing and Mr. Daryl Martin, Project Manager, Premium Environmental Services, respectively, called with a report of a spill.  On June 9, 2020, at approximately 1800 hours, a semitruck got into a multi-car accident.  This resulted in a leak of an estimated 150 gallons of diesel fuel on the southbound shoulder of Highway 43 near Panther Creek, Tatum, Rusk County, Texas.  The coordinates where the spill occurred are North 32.27042 degrees and West -94.6-0658 degrees.

The semi-truck that leaked the diesel fuel was owned by: 

SRT Oil Field Service
PO Box 2909
Laurel, MI 39440
Phone - (601) 498-1197 
POC: Ms. Marjorie Hylton, CFO

phys_loc_desc_txt: Approximately two miles offshore in State waters
comments: TCEQ R14 will continue to gather information and assess the situation.
action: On September 1, 2020, via telephone, Mr. Bill Ross, Emergency Response Coordinator (ERC) with TCEQ R14 contacted Magellan E&P Holdings to gather additional information. Mr. James Haley, ERC with TCEQ R14 contacted Mr. Billy Delgado, Corpus Christi Emergency Management Coordinator and Chief Robert Rocha with the Corpus Christi Fire Department.
description: On September 1, 2020, at approximately 1032 hours, the TCEQ R14 received notification from a private citizen concerned with of an unknown release and gasoline like odor with an accompanying roar from an off-shore gas well platform (926 Well) located in the Gulf of Mexico. The incident was determined to be an uncontrolled release of natural gas and condensate from a gas well. The Responsible Party (RP) was determined to be Magellan E&P Holdings, Inc. (Magellan). The RP contracted Witt Obrien's to manage the release and Great White Well Control to regain operational control of the well and conduct repairs to the system. Witt Obrien submitted a subsequent notification for the release via CHEMTEL Report Number 20202817.

The cause was thought to be roofing felt related to a roofing project on a car port at the base. However, it was subsequently determined to be a leaking used oil container. reg_ent_name: EDDIE MARTINEZ DBA MARTINEZ NEW & USED TIRES
action:
On December 6, 2017 at approximately 16:30 hours, investigator Dale Vodak, P.G., arrived at the location.  The investigator met with Mr. Eric Lowry and Ms. Caitlin Roberson, Deputy Smith County Fire Marshals.  Mr. Lowry explained that they were still investigating the fire at the facility. The investigator observed that the fire was contained to the storage shed on the south side of the property.  During the investigation, the investigator was accompanied by Mr. Jack Holsomback, TCEQ Small Business & Local Government Program.

Several Smith County fire departments reportedly responded to the fire at this location.  Class A foam and water were used to minimize the amount of water used to extinguish the fire.  Based on observations onsite, the fire water appears to have been contained onsite. This site is located directly across the street from Lake Palestine, Neches River Basin (Segment 0605).  The small shed was totally destroyed by the fire, along with itโs contents.  

As a part of the investigation, the investigator also conducted an evaluation of their current scrap tire management practices.  At the rear of the property, there was a large pile of scrap tires, left over from the former operator of the business, Mr. Eddie Martinez.  The scrap tire pile was measured and the investigator calculated it contained 2,000 Passenger Tire Equivalents (PTEs).  

 According to Mr. Lowry, Mr. Martinez has relinquished his business to a new operator, Mr. Travis Coslett.   The transfer of ownership of the business was reportedly going to occur on December 15, 2017.

The investigator and Mr. Holsomback met briefly with Mr. Coslett before leaving the site.  Mr. Coslett stated he was operating the business in the interim since Mr. Martinez left.  The property owner, Mr. John Appel had previously contacted the investigator about the scrap tire pile.  In an email, he indicated he was making arrangement to have a semi-trailer brought in by Benton Rainey Tire & Recovery, a registered scrap tire transporter and processor.  Previously, Mr. Appel had a trailer load of scrap tires removed.  The investigator attempted to contact Mr. Martinez on December 7, 2017, but phone number no longer works.


CONCLUSION

There did not appear to be any significant impact from the firewater discharges from this fire, as it did not appear to have left the site.  Therefore, this incident should be closed with no further action needed. This emergency incident is being closed.  At this time, the Tyler Region is still working with Mr. Appel on the removal of the scrap tires.

action: On September 19, 2018, a response action report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office. The Irving Police and Fire Departments responded to the incident and used absorbents to contain the spill.  Lone Star Hazmat Response used absorbent booms, pads, and ash to contain the spill. The waste generated during the cleanup activities was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417B) in Alvarado (Jonson County), Texas.  Based on the information received, it appears no further action is warranted at this time.

comments:
On March 19, 2020, Ms. Jillian Layton, Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Region 10 Emergency Response (ER) Coordinator, received notification from Chemtel (20200966) and the National Response Center (NRC) (Report 1273817).

On March 19, 2020, at approximately 11:14 hours, Ms. Jillian Layton, TCEQ Region 10 ER Coordinator, telephoned Mr. Renalli to discuss the incident. Mr. Renalli stated that while personnel were filling a tanker truck with Ammonium Thiosulfate a valve on the tanker truck was inadvertently left open, resulting in the release of material to the ground. No off-site impacts were noted and water sources were not impacted.
action:
Actions taken in response to the spill were reported to include the building of a berm, the utilization of absorbent pads, the vacuuming up of standing liquid, and excavation of the impacted area.

No onsite investigation was conducted for this incident.

NOT A REPORTABLE SPILL.

incident_nature: BLANK - USED BY PROGRAMS NOT REQUIRING NATURE CODE
comments:
On December 29, 2020, at approximately 0900 hours, investigator Tom Erny went to the location of the spill. The truck involved in the accident had been removed and there were no response personnel on site.  The spilled diesel fuel onsite was contained using absorbent.  The spill appeared to be contained and there did not appear to be any impact to waters of the State.  A phone call was made to Mr. Ron McHam, Project Manager, Crow Towing.  Mr. McHam indicated they would be excavating the contaminated soils later in the day.

On December 28, 2020, the investigator, gave verbal directives to Mr. Ronald McHam to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.
action: The TCEQ Tyler office will continue to monitor the remediation of the spill.

On October 7, 2020, the investigator, gave verbal directives Ms. Lori Brown, Project Manager, Crow Towing to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

comments: On September 16, 2020, Mr. Tidwell called Mr. McCrummen stating a Texas Tech University laboratory had run analyses on water samples, collected from the lakes, and determined the cause of the fish kill was due to golden algae.
action: On September 15 and 16, 2020, Messrs. Jay Keith, Section Manager, and Dan McCrummen, Environmental Investigator, with the TCEQ Region 2 Lubbock Office travelled to the site.  There were dead fish observed in Lakes 1, 2 and 3.  The investigators estimated there were multiple thousands of dead fish.  The largest number of deads were in Lake 1 and the numbers decreased in Lakes 2 and 3.  There were no dead fish observed in Lakes 4 through 6.  Upon completion of the site investigation, a cause could not be determined.

comments: TCEQ Region 14 will continue to gather information and assess the situation.
action:
On September 6, 2018 at 1028 hours, Mr. Brice Thomas, Emergency Response Coordinator (ERC) with the TCEQ R14 Corpus Christi Office, contacted Mr. Daniel Davis, Response Officer with the Texas General Land Office (TGLO), via telephone to gather additional information and determine the status of any abatement and remediation actions. Mr. Davis stated that the TGLO considers the sheen from Valero outfall 006 to have originated from the same oil sump at the heavy cracking unit previously investigated on August 10, 2018 (Incident #292323).

On September 6, 2018 at 1301 hours, Mr. Thomas contacted Ms. Faren Von Duben, Environmental Engineer with the RP, to gather additional information. Ms. Von Duben stated that outfall 006 was closed and in-house staff and the CCAOSCA had deployed absorbent boom at the storm water drain near the heavy cracking unit and at outfall 006. Ms. Von Duben further stated that the RP had not yet conducted remediation measures for the previous release on August 10, 2018. Mr. Thomas requested that all response and remediation measures taken by the RP be documented in the Spill Remediation Report requested on August 10, 2018.
description: On September 6, 2018 at 1014 hours, the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Region 14 (R14) Corpus Christi Office received a notification via NRC Incident Reports #1223778 and #1223780 of a release of an unknown amount of an unknown oil to the Corpus Christi Ship Channel from an oil sump due to human error. The release occurred at 5900 Up River Road in Corpus Christi (Nueces County), Texas. The Responsible Party (RP) was determined to be Valero Refining - Texas LP. The RP utilized in-house staff and contracted with the Corpus Christi Area Oil Spill Control Association (CCAOSCA) to handle response and remediation of the spill.

action: On November 20, 2019, a final cleanup spill report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office via email and on November 22, 2019 via postal mail. The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, a site map, and sample results. On October 11, 2019, Primoris responded on-site, set up booms and absorbent pads to contain the oil on the concrete, vacuumed the product, and washed the impacted concrete. The mineral oil that entered the stormwater system was unrecoverable because the outfall could not be located. On October 16, 2019, Primoris crews returned to the site to excavate impacted soil and backfilled the area with clean soil. On November 12, 2019, a confirmation sample and a background sample were collected from the site and sent to TTI Environmental Laboratories in Arlington, Texas. On November 14, 2019, the soil samples came back as undetectable for Total Petroleum Hydrocarbons (TPH). The contaminated waste will be temporarily stored pending bulk disposal on a periodic basis. Oncor will submit disposal documentation after the next bulk disposal.

comments:
On August 15, 2019, Mr. Petty submitted a final clean up report for the aforementioned release (See Attachment 1). The final report consisted of a description of the cleanup activities performed by E3, site location map, sample collection map, photographs, laboratory analysis report and waste disposal documentation. 

According to the cleanup report, the release consisted of approximately 150 gallons of diesel fuel. On July 8, 2019, clean-up efforts were initiated by placing granular absorbent on the impacted area. Contaminated absorbent was collected and transported by E3 Services (EPA ID: TXR000083939) to be disposed at the Ponderosa Regional Landfill (RN100629310 MSW#2286) in Laredo, Texas. On July 9, 2019, impacted soil was excavated utilizing a backhoe and stockpiled nearby. The excavated soil generated during this remediation was stockpiled in four 20 cubic yard roll-off boxes for transport and disposal. 

On July 10, 2019, three confirmation soil samples and one background soil sample were collected and sent for analysis to Pace Analytical in Mount Juliet, Tennessee for analyses. The soil samples were analyzed for Benzene, Toluene, Ethylbenzene, Xylenes (BTEX), and methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE) by EPA Method 8260 and total petroleum hydrocarbons (TPH) by EPA Method TX1005. BTEX, MTBE, and TPH were below their respective laboratory Method Quantitation Limits (MQLs) in confirmation and background soil samples submitted for analysis. Two drums of diesel impacted absorbent, two drums of diesel water mixture, and 72 yards of diesel impacted soils were disposed of on July 12, 2019 at Ponderosa Regional Landfill in Laredo, Texas.
action: After reviewing the details of the incident, it was determined that appropriate actions had been taken by the responsible party to address the aforementioned release. No further actions by the TCEQ are warranted at this time.
description: On July 7, 2019, Ms. Aguirre received an ER notification of an estimated 150-gallon diesel fuel release which originated from a third-party truck which caught fire and the saddle tanks ruptured. Diesel fuel spilled onto the asphalt surface, migrated to a nearby storm drainage area (not entering the drain), and impacted soil adjacent to the asphalt surface. The incident was reported by Mr. Jason Petty, Project Scientist with Broadbent & Associates, who is an environmental consultant for Pilot Travel Centers LLC. Pilot Travel Centers LLC is the Responsible Party for this incident. Enhanced Environmental and Emergency Services (E3) was contracted to handle the clean-up at the site. The spill was contained on site by applying granular absorbent material to the impacted asphalt and was collected in 55-gallon steel drums. Soil was impacted. This incident did not meet the criteria for Homeland Security notification.
