comments: Based on the Memorandum of Understanding between the RRC and TCEQ (16 Texas Administrative Code Chapter 3 Rule ยง3.30), this ER incident is under the jurisdiction of the RRC. Ms. Serna emailed and sent a hard copy of a referral letter to the attention of Ms. Clement on May 22, 2019. As this ER incident is under the RRC jurisdiction, no further action is required by TCEQ.
action:
Due to the potential health effects to human health on neighboring properties, Ms. Serna and Mr. Salinas conducted an immediate response to assess the area the same day of the notification at approximately 1830 hours. Upon arrival, the investigators observed the saltwater spill impacting a third party property located south of the salt water disposal facility. The release was caused by a third party contractor conducting land clearing operations, which resulted in the accidental excavation of a 3 inch and 4 inch line from the disposal facility. As a result, the lines burst and released an unknown amount of saltwater onto a third party property to the west of the saltwater disposal facility (See attachment 1). No odors were noted. No sheen was observed. Using the MultiRAE, no readings were noted. The owner of the salt water disposal facility, Mr. Marcos Espinoza, arrived on site at approximately 1900 hours. Mr. Espinoza stated that the well, which is part of the facility's impacted lines, had been out of service for approximately one year. 

At approximately 1930 hours, the investigators proceeded to an additional residential property that was affected by the spilled material to the west of the spill area. A significant amount of saltwater was also observed to have impacted the property (See attachment 2). The investigators explained to the affected property owner that the spill will need to be remediated by the responsible party and that this incident is under the jurisdiction of the Railroad Commission of Texas (RRC). The investigators departed the scene and returned to the regional office. 

The same day, Ms. Serna contacted Ms. Brooklyn Clement, Assistant Director with the RRC Corpus Christi office, to notify of the ER incident. Ms. Clement stated that a RRC Investigator would be assigned to the case and would be deployed to assess the incident. Details of the incident and information gathered during the immediate on site response was provided to Ms. Clement.
description: On May 18, 2019, at approximately 1800 hours, a notification via phone call from Mr. Jose Alejandro, District Coordinator with the Texas Division of Emergency Management, was received by Mr. Jose Salinas, Environmental Investigator with the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) Laredo Region Office (LRO). The notification stated that a saltwater disposal well pipeline located off of Highway 359 in Laredo, Texas, had ruptured at approximately 1630 hours and released an unknown amount of liquid. The cause of the spill was unknown. The spill was said to be a land release only. This was not a significant incident. This incident did not meet the criteria for Homeland Security notification. This emergency response (ER) incident was assigned to Mr. Sheila Serna, TCEQ LRO Environmental Investigator.

comments:
On June 8, 2020, at approximately 1615 hours, the investigator went to the location of the spill. There were no response personnel at the location and the truck involved in the accident had been removed.  The area of impacted area had been cleaned and there was no sheen or product observed in Little Saline Creek (Segment 0505) in the Sabine River Basin.  

On June 8, 2020, the investigator, gave verbal directives Ms. Lori Brown, Project Manager, Crow Towing to submit a written report to the attention of the investigator for this incident, no later than 30 working days from the incident. At a minimum, the report is to describe the details of the discharge or spill, a statement that the discharge or spill response action has been completed, a description of how the response action was conducted, proof of disposal of any contaminated media to an approved facility, and photographs for verification.

action: On May 26, 2020, a final cleanup spill report was received by the TCEQ DFW Region Office.  The report included a description of the incident, cleanup actions taken, and disposal documentation. Absorbent material was used to contain the spill. A vacuum truck was used to remove the affected ballast and the ballast rock and soil were excavated. Microbial surfactant was applied onto the affected area to degrade residual oil. The waste generated was disposed at Turkey Creek Landfill (Municipal Solid Waste Permit No. 1417C) in Alvarado (Johnson County), Texas. Based on the information received it appears this incident did not exceed the reportable quantity for oil under Title 30 Texas Administrative Code Chapter 327. No further action is warranted at this time.
